segments.content: Screenplay by
Randy Feldman

He's listening to the stretch call of a horse race, and he's 

               into it.
...at the top of the stretch it's
Cozy Girl in front with Backtrack
coming on... Cozy Girl by a length,
Backtrack closing...
The CAMERA GRADUALLY pulls back to reveal that Roper is driving his Trans Am across the Bay Bridge. HELICOPTER SHOTS give a soaring view of the San Francisco skyline.

character.name: Come on. Stay up there, Cozy Girl...

dialogue.text: The CAMERA GRADUALLY pulls back to reveal that Roper is driving his Trans Am across the Bay Bridge. HELICOPTER SHOTS give a soaring view of the San Francisco skyline.

segments.content: At the eighth pole it's Cozy Girl by
half a length... Backtrack closing...
Roper's police radio SQUAWKS.
He picks up the radio.

dialogue.text: He picks up the radio.

segments.content: Dig in, Cozy Girl...
(into the radio)
Roper go.
One-four, Roper. Code 2.C.P. 4th and
Grand.
It's Cozy Girl holding on... Cozy
Girl and Backtrack...
He tosses the radio down. Punches the accelerator.

character.name: I'm en route. E.T.A. in five.

dialogue.text: He tosses the radio down. Punches the accelerator.

segments.content: Stay up there, Girl...
Cozy Girl in front by a neck... Now
a head...
Weaving through traffic on the bridge.
Where's the damn wire?!
Here comes the wire... and...
Backtrack gets up in the last jump.
Cozy girl a very game second.
The Trans Am streak off toward the city.

A hostage situation. Police barricades. Dozens of squad cars, 

               ambulances, spectators, SWAT team. It's a stalemate. Roper's 

               Trans Am pulls to a stop at the barricades. He hops out, 

               weaves through the spectators and past the barriers.

               A FEMALE DETECTIVE, EIKO KIMURA, rushes up to him.
Hi, Roper.
Kimura points to the diner in the middle of the block. Roper heads toward it. As they walk Kimura briefs him...

character.name: Hi, Kimura. Where's the command post?

dialogue.text: Kimura points to the diner in the middle of the block. Roper heads toward it. As they walk Kimura briefs him...

segments.content: The suspect came in shortly after
the bank opened. Botched robbery. A
teller hit the silent alarm. He took

heading.subject: seven hostages. Shot one -- the guard.
heading.raw_text: seven hostages. Shot one -- the guard.

segments.content: He's still alive. So far he's asked
for...
...a car.
That's right, and a plane waiting at
the airport. If he doesn't...
...get 'em, he's going to start
shooting hostages in five minutes...
That's right.
What's the suspect's name?

INT. DINER - DAY Across from the bank. This is where the "command post" is setup. About a dozen cops and the accompanying support staff are here. Lieutenant SAMUEL BAFFERT is in charge. Roper saunters in.

dialogue.text: INT. DINER - DAY Across from the bank. This is where the "command post" is setup. About a dozen cops and the accompanying support staff are here. Lieutenant SAMUEL BAFFERT is in charge. Roper saunters in.

segments.content: Hello, guys.
Hello, Roper. Glad you could join
us.
Roper walks over to the counter where Baffert is standing.
Baffert hands him a folder. Roper opens it.

character.name: Do we have a profile on Mr. Earl?

dialogue.text: Baffert hands him a folder. Roper opens it.

segments.content: Roper scans the profile.

dialogue.text: Roper scans the profile.

segments.content: They're not usually graduate students.
SWAT wants to go in.
What's the rush? They haven't killed
anybody yet this week?
Roper refers to the folder.
We got a guy who's probably on drugs.
He's got a record of 459's and he
was busted on possession. But he's
never been busted on a major felony.
What's his demeanor?
Well he's a little fucking agitated --
he ripped the phone out.
I have to go face to face.
No -- you can't do that.
You got 7 hostages in there, 1 of
them's wounded -- We don't know how
bad it is -- The guy ripped the phone
out -- SWAT said he's got a gun to
the head of a female hostage. If
SWAT makes entry now, you're gonna
lose 1 hostage, maybe 2. I gotta go
in. Maybe I can see what's going on
in there.
I don't know.
He's never offed anybody. His rap
doesn't show any violence.
Not that we know of.
We don't know how much time we have.
If I can get in to talk to him --
maybe we won't lose anyone.
Maybe we can get a throw phone in
there.
SWAT says it's broken -- The perp in
the last situation rendered it
inoperable.
What do you mean?
He urinated on it and shorted out
the circuits.
We gonna stand here and talk about
it or let the guy in there bleed to
death.
(beat... beat)

Roper pulls out his gun and places it on the counter. EXT. STREET - DAY Roper eats the donut as he crosses toward the bank. EXT. ROOFTOP ACROSS THE STREET - DAY A team of two SWAT TEAM MEMBERS, FORBES IS A SPOTTER AND MCCALL IS A SHARPSHOOTER. KEVIN MCCALL, is the one we're interested in. He's 25 years old, handsome, all American. He's the best the SWAT team has. He crouches motionless, staring through the scope of his rifle, watching as Roper calmly walks toward the bank.

dialogue.text: Roper pulls out his gun and places it on the counter. EXT. STREET - DAY Roper eats the donut as he crosses toward the bank. EXT. ROOFTOP ACROSS THE STREET - DAY A team of two SWAT TEAM MEMBERS, FORBES IS A SPOTTER AND MCCALL IS A SHARPSHOOTER. KEVIN MCCALL, is the one we're interested in. He's 25 years old, handsome, all American. He's the best the SWAT team has. He crouches motionless, staring through the scope of his rifle, watching as Roper calmly walks toward the bank.

segments.content: What do you think he's got in the
bag?
Donuts.
You can't take a guy down with a
donut.

A tense situation. A wild-eyed, white punk, fuck-up of a 

               BANK ROBBER, EARL, is holding a pretty, young TELLER around 

               the neck with a cocked gun held to her temple.

               The other bank employees are cowering on the floor. A few 

               are giving aid to the wounded bank guard who is half-conscious 

               and oozing blood from his side.

               Roper strolls right through the front door and walks toward 

               Earl, very sociable.
Hi, Earl, I'm Scott Roper. Wanna
donut? I ate the glazed but there's
a bunch of chocolate and a --
Earl swipes the donuts out of Roper's hand and starts frisking
Roper for weapons with his free hand. The other hand still
has the gun poised at the young teller's head.
I'm a negotiator, Earl. I don't carry
a weapon.
Roper smiles reassuringly at the pretty teller. It seems to
help. Earl finishes patting Roper down, straightens back up
and puts his hand around the teller's neck.
Where's the car?
I need to get something straight
first.
Roper looks over at the other bank employees huddled on the
floor.
A balding, middle-aged MAN sheepishly raises his hand.

dialogue.text: A balding, middle-aged MAN sheepishly raises his hand.

segments.content: Roper takes a step toward him.

dialogue.text: Roper takes a step toward him.

segments.content: When did you start keeping longer
hours?
Last spring.
Really! Because I've been thinking
of moving to this branch. It would
be really convenient for me --
Earl wags his gun against the Teller's ear.
Do you want me to start killing
people?!
Roper holds his hand up defensively.
It's my job to see that no one gets
killed, Earl... Including you.
Earl is pouring sweat. His gun hand is shaking uncontrollably.

dialogue.text: Earl is pouring sweat. His gun hand is shaking uncontrollably.

segments.content: I'm getting it, Earl, but we have to
do this the right way.
Roper keeps his eyes locked on Earl. His voice is calm.
First I need you to point that gun
away from --
(to the teller)
What's your name?
(voice trembling)
Debbie...
Point the gun away from Debbie.
Debbie's brains are going to be
splattered all over the floor if I
don't see a car in five minutes!
Roper takes a long look at Earl. The guy is a hair trigger.
Alright! But let's be clear about
one thing. If you kill someone, I
can't help you. The SWAT guys will
take you out.
Earl glances at the army of cop cars poised outside. Reflects
for a moment on the reality of the situation.
What are my chances of getting out
of here?
Roper calmly moves toward where the wounded guard is laying.
Not bad. Last month, a guy robbed a
bank in Daly City...
Roper crouches down, smiles at the blurry-eyed guard.
The guard groans. He's not doing very well. Roper peels back the bloody handkerchief, takes a look. Winces.

dialogue.text: The guard groans. He's not doing very well. Roper peels back the bloody handkerchief, takes a look. Winces.

segments.content: (to Earl)
...Cops gave him a car, and he lost
them on the freeway.
Earl is encouraged by that.
Really?
Absolutely. Bank robbers are generally
your smartest criminals.
Roper looks directly into Earl's eyes.
Roper bends over the guard.

dialogue.text: Roper bends over the guard.

segments.content: He grabs the guard under the arms and starts dragging him across the floor. The guard MOANS piteously.

dialogue.text: He grabs the guard under the arms and starts dragging him across the floor. The guard MOANS piteously.

segments.content: Hey, leave him alone. What are you
doing?
Roper keeps dragging the guard toward the front door.
It's part of my negotiator's oath.
If there's an injured party and I
can help them, I'm duty bound by my
oath to do that. You can shoot me if
you want, but the next negotiator in
here is going to tell you the same
thing.
Earl is unsure what to do, but he guesses an oath is an oath.
He lets Roper drag the guard to the door.
I'll be right back, Earl. Point that
gun away from Debbie.
Earl compliantly moves the gun away from the teller's head,
then re-thinks and jerks it back against her temple.

Roper drags the guard out the front door and deposits him on 

               the sidewalk. Two SWAT OFFICERS rush up to give aid. One of 

               them is Jennings.
(whispering to Jennings)
Jennings inconspicuously pulls his gun out and slips it to him. Roper quickly cocks it and shoves it in his waistband under his shirt and vest.

dialogue.parenthetical: (NOTE: The method of disarming Earl is still to be determined)
dialogue.text: Jennings inconspicuously pulls his gun out and slips it to him. Roper quickly cocks it and shoves it in his waistband under his shirt and vest.

segments.content: I haven't had to shoot anyone in
three years.
Why not keep the streak alive?
Because this strung-out junkie is
too stupid to get out of this without
killing somebody.

Earl watches Roper through the window. He can only see Roper's 

               back. He's getting very agitated.
(yelling)

heading.subject: HEY, WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU DOING OUT
heading.raw_text: HEY, WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU DOING OUT

segments.content:
The two cops hustle off with the wounded guard, and Roper 

               calmly walks back into the bank. Stops about five paces from 

               Earl.
As a rule, I need one hostage released
as show of good faith.
Roper glances at Debbie. Gun pressed against her head. Tears
start rolling down her cheeks. She's being tremendously brave.
Earl squeezes the gun even tighter against the side of her head.

dialogue.text: Earl squeezes the gun even tighter against the side of her head.

segments.content: The other hostages watch this exchange tensely.

dialogue.text: The other hostages watch this exchange tensely.

segments.content: The Old Guy? What kind of show of
faith is that? I want Debbie.
Am I gettin' the car?
Earl thinks about it, his gun hand twitching. He points at two of the female employees cowering against the counter.

dialogue.text: Earl thinks about it, his gun hand twitching. He points at two of the female employees cowering against the counter.

segments.content: Roper decides that this is the best he's going to get.

dialogue.text: Roper decides that this is the best he's going to get.

segments.content: The two women don't need any extra encouragement. They jump up and rush out the front door. EXT. ROOFTOP - DAY McCall and Forbes watch through their rifle scopes as the two released hostages are whisked away by uniformed cops.

dialogue.text: The two women don't need any extra encouragement. They jump up and rush out the front door. EXT. ROOFTOP - DAY McCall and Forbes watch through their rifle scopes as the two released hostages are whisked away by uniformed cops.

segments.content: This guy is good.
INT. BANK - DAY

dialogue.text: INT. BANK - DAY

segments.content: That was fine, Earl. Now I'm going
to get your car.
Roper turns around and walks toward the front door. He stops
and looks over his shoulder.
Earl looks like he's right on the edge.

dialogue.text: Earl looks like he's right on the edge.

segments.content: What?!
Earl thinks about that for a beat...

character.name: You want a convertible or hardtop?

dialogue.text: Earl thinks about that for a beat...

segments.content: Roper turns around, starts walking again. He keeps his eyes focused on the reflection of Earl in the front window of the bank.

dialogue.text: Roper turns around, starts walking again. He keeps his eyes focused on the reflection of Earl in the front window of the bank.

segments.content: (without turning around)
Manual or automatic?
Automatic.

In one swift motion, Roper turns, aims and FIRES!... One SHOT. It tears into Earl's shoulder. One inch from Debbie's neck. Earl is blown back against the counter. Debbie shrieks at the top of her lungs. SWAT guys pour in from every entrance. YELLING for everybody to "GET DOWN"! Pointing guns. They pounce on Earl.

dialogue.text: In one swift motion, Roper turns, aims and FIRES!... One SHOT. It tears into Earl's shoulder. One inch from Debbie's neck. Earl is blown back against the counter. Debbie shrieks at the top of her lungs. SWAT guys pour in from every entrance. YELLING for everybody to "GET DOWN"! Pointing guns. They pounce on Earl.

segments.content: Roper goes to Debbie, puts his arm around her and gently leads her out of the bank. EXT. ROOFTOP - DAY McCall and Forbes still have their rifles trained on the bank door. Their police radio squawks...

character.name: I give up! I give up!

dialogue.text: Roper goes to Debbie, puts his arm around her and gently leads her out of the bank. EXT. ROOFTOP - DAY McCall and Forbes still have their rifles trained on the bank door. Their police radio squawks...

segments.content: The situation is secured. Suspect in
custody. Repeat. Situation secured.
McCall lowers his rifle as Roper guides Debbie through the
wave of cops rushing into the bank.

Roper is exiting the bank and putting back on his gun when 

               he hears the sound of a CAMERA SHUTTER. He turns to see 

               VERONICA (RONNIE) TATE holding the camera. She snaps one of 

               Roper with Earl in the b.g. being placed in a squad car.
Roper puts his hand over his heart as if stricken with love... which he in fact is.

character.name: There's one for the front page.

dialogue.text: Roper puts his hand over his heart as if stricken with love... which he in fact is.

segments.content: Ronnie, why are you torturing me? I
can't live without you.
Ronnie rolls her eyes. She doesn't take Roper all that
seriously.
She slings the camera over her shoulder and starts to walk off. Roper dogs her.

dialogue.text: She slings the camera over her shoulder and starts to walk off. Roper dogs her.

segments.content: This baseball player you're going
out with...
(shaking his head)
He's no good for you.
Really?! He's a wonderful guy. He
makes two million a year, and he
worships me.
I worship you.
You worship yourself.
Ronnie, forget this what's-his-name.
Greg.
Did you know he's already got a bad
knee? In another 10 years you're
going to be pushing him around in a
wheelchair.
Ronnie stops. Looks him in the eye.
You know what I think? I think you
only want me now, because I'm with
somebody else.
Who cares what you think. I want you
back and that's all that matters.
Ronnie smiles, but offers no response.
Let me take you out tomorrow night...
Pleeease.
I'm going out with Greg tomorrow.
(frowning)
This Greg is really getting in my
way.
Roper gets down on his knees.
Please. I'm begging you.

heading.subject: Oh, I've got to get a shot of this.
heading.raw_text: Oh, I've got to get a shot of this.

segments.content:
She takes the lense cap off her camera. Roper primps his 

               hair to make sure he looks good for the picture... CLICK! 

               Suddenly Roper notices that his Trans Am is being towed. He 

               rushes over to his car.
A REPO MAN stands off to the side watching dispassionately.

dialogue.text: A REPO MAN stands off to the side watching dispassionately.

segments.content: Not anymore. Now it belongs to Silver

Roper sadly watches the tow truck drive off with his beloved Trans Am. INT. METRO DIVISION HEADQUARTERS - DAY - RAINING Lots of activity. Officers in cubicles; talking on phones; typing reports on computers. Most are plain-clothed. Roper weaves through the room. Passes by Baffert's desk.

dialogue.text: Roper sadly watches the tow truck drive off with his beloved Trans Am. INT. METRO DIVISION HEADQUARTERS - DAY - RAINING Lots of activity. Officers in cubicles; talking on phones; typing reports on computers. Most are plain-clothed. Roper weaves through the room. Passes by Baffert's desk.

segments.content: Hey, Baffert, what's the story for
tonight?
Baffert pulls two tickets for the Warriors' game out of his
pocket.
Floor seats.
You're my hero.
Dinner's on you.

INT. HALLWAY - DAY - RAINING A quiet contrast to the squadroom. This is the executive branch of Metro. All the big-wigs are officed here. Roper walks down the carpeted hall. No one here except Kevin McCall quietly sitting outside Captain Solis' office. Roper and McCall make brief eye contact. Roper thinks nothing of it. He goes into the Captain's office. INT. CAPTAIN SOLIS' OFFICE - RAINING CAPTAIN FRANK SOLIS is on the phone. There's a file on the desk in front of him. He motions Roper to sit down.

dialogue.text: INT. HALLWAY - DAY - RAINING A quiet contrast to the squadroom. This is the executive branch of Metro. All the big-wigs are officed here. Roper walks down the carpeted hall. No one here except Kevin McCall quietly sitting outside Captain Solis' office. Roper and McCall make brief eye contact. Roper thinks nothing of it. He goes into the Captain's office. INT. CAPTAIN SOLIS' OFFICE - RAINING CAPTAIN FRANK SOLIS is on the phone. There's a file on the desk in front of him. He motions Roper to sit down.

segments.content: He just walked into my office.
(looks over at Roper)
The Chief says, "Good work this
morning. Congratulations."
Roper smiles as he sits down.
Tell him to give me a raise.
(into the phone)
He says, "Thank you very much."
(a beat)
I'll discuss it with him right now...
Solis hangs up. Looks across the desk at Roper. A long pause. He knows he's got leverage.

dialogue.text: Solis hangs up. Looks across the desk at Roper. A long pause. He knows he's got leverage.

segments.content: Roper.
What?
Are you going to make this hard for
me?
Depends. What's up?
There's been some concern about you
continuing to work without back-up.
Solis dumps his cards on the table.

dialogue.text: Solis dumps his cards on the table.

segments.content: What if you die and no one can do
what you do as well as you do it?
Your concern is heartwarming.
It's been decided that you take on
another partner and train him to be
able to take over for you.
Is that what the guy in the Sunday
School suit is doing outside?
His name's Kevin McCall. Every Metro
Captain agrees that he's their top
sharp-shooter and most likely to
succeed.
Roper grabs McCall's folder off the desk.
Roper scans it.

dialogue.text: Roper scans it.

segments.content: Tested high on his intellectual
aptitude... Not as high as me but...
National marksman finalist... Attended
N. Y. C... Went to college. Very
impressive. F.B.I. sniper school...
INT. HALLWAY - SAME - RAINING McCall turns around in his chair. He can see Roper and Solis through the glass walls of the office, but he can't hear their voices. INT. SOLIS' OFFICE - SAME - RAINING

dialogue.text: INT. HALLWAY - SAME - RAINING McCall turns around in his chair. He can see Roper and Solis through the glass walls of the office, but he can't hear their voices. INT. SOLIS' OFFICE - SAME - RAINING

segments.content: "Additional Skills": Biathelete,
marathoner, lip-reading, speaks
Roper throws the folder back on the desk.

dialogue.text: Roper throws the folder back on the desk.

segments.content: Great, send him to the Marines. This
guy's not a negotiator. He'll quit
in two weeks.
You let us worry about that.
Is there going to be an expression
of your appreciation?
(gloomily)
What kind of appreciation are we
talking about?
The financial kind. I figure I'm
going to be working extra hours. All
sorts of overtime... training
sessions... Not to mention the extra
stress...
What do you think would be in order?
Like ahh... I don't know...
(boldly)
Five thousand dollars.
(calmly)
Uh-oh, Roper thinks maybe he sold short.

character.name: Okay, I think I could swing that.

dialogue.text: Uh-oh, Roper thinks maybe he sold short.

segments.content: (quickly)
And a car.
Hey, you just got a five thousand
dollar raise. Get a car of your own.
You know you've got nothing but cars
down there in impound.
Impound isn't a rent-a-car company.
(firmly)
The car is part of the deal.
Solis gets up and taps the glass, motions for McCall to come in.

character.name: What happened to your Trans Am?

dialogue.text: Solis gets up and taps the glass, motions for McCall to come in.

segments.content: Repoed this morning.
(relenting)
I'll provide you with transportation.
And even if this doesn't work, I
want all the money. These SWAT guys
don't have the temperament. They
don't have the background...
McCall enters the office.
(instant character
change)
Hey, glad to meet you. I've heard
nothing but good things about you...
Roper reaches out. They shake hands.
Same here. I've watched you in action.
Very impressive.
You've got a lot of hard work ahead
of you if you want to be a negotiator.
I'm ready to do it.
(a beat)
And I'm going to be here more than
two weeks.
Roper's face darkens.
Don't go reading my lips, man. That's
an intrusion. Save that shit for the
sniper school. Comprende?
Sorry... Habit.
(intervening)
Roper smiles.

dialogue.text: Roper smiles.

segments.content: We're already past it, aren't we,
Kevin?
If you say so.
Then you'll have to excuse me. I
have other work to do.
Roper and McCall head out the door.
Roper turns back around.

dialogue.text: Roper turns back around.

segments.content: About the transportation issue...
Roper smiles. Total victory. INT. HALLWAY - DAY - RAINING MOVING with Roper and McCall.

character.name: You check with the impound sergeant.

dialogue.text: Roper smiles. Total victory. INT. HALLWAY - DAY - RAINING MOVING with Roper and McCall.

segments.content: You ever been in a hostage situation?
Only at the very end.
How do you feel after a shooting.
(self-assured)
They enter the squadroom, wind through the cubicles.

character.name: Like it had to be done.

dialogue.text: They enter the squadroom, wind through the cubicles.

segments.content: It rarely has to be done.
SWAT is a lifesaving unit, you know.
(flatly)
I know.
They arrive at Roper's desk.

dialogue.text: They arrive at Roper's desk.

segments.content: Roper grabs an empty soda bottle from a neighboring desk. He takes the cap off a ball point pen and drops it into the empty bottle. He places the bottle on his desk.

dialogue.text: Roper grabs an empty soda bottle from a neighboring desk. He takes the cap off a ball point pen and drops it into the empty bottle. He places the bottle on his desk.

segments.content: Extract that pen cap without touching
or moving the bottle.
McCall looks at the bottle quizzically.
What's the point of this?
A little exercise in lateral thinking.
The obvious solution isn't always
the only solution... See you tomorrow.
Roper grabs his jacket and walks off, leaving McCall to ponder
the problem. McCall looks over at another cop who has been
observing. The cop shrugs his shoulders. He hasn't got a
clue. McCall sits down and thoughtfully peers into the bottle.
Sequence omitted from original script.

Roper and Baffert walking past the row of cars, including 

               Solis' cadillac, searching for Roper's "new" transportation... 

               Roper is holding the keys in his hand.
Mind if we make a stop on the way?
We busted Frank Antonucci on
possession. He gave us a lead on
that Polk Street jewelry heist.
"Phoney Frank"? Don't waste your
time. He'd tell you his granny was
in on the Kennedy assassination if
he could dodge a collar.
I still gotta do it. Wasting time is
half my job.
Roper is looking at the numbered parking spaces.

dialogue.text: Roper is looking at the numbered parking spaces.

segments.content: This SWAT guy might be a good idea.
He may be able to take a little
pressure off you. I worry about you.
You worried about me, too? The chief's
worried about me. Solis is worried
about me. Maybe you guys should start
some kind of organization.
Speaking of which. I saw you talking
to Ronnie this morning. Why can't
you get it back together with her.
You've gotta be out of your mind not
to get with that one.
It's not me. It's her. She's going
out with this baseball player --
Greg Barnett.
(impressed)
No shit! He's good!
Fuck him. He swings at anything in
the dirt. I could strike him out.
Don't give up on her. You're getting
to the age when you ought to be
thinking about these things.
Roper bends over like an old man.
They arrive at their destination. A parking space with a 1957 DODGE PICKUP.

character.name: Yep, my rheumatism's been acting up.

dialogue.text: They arrive at their destination. A parking space with a 1957 DODGE PICKUP.

segments.content: Roper looks at the pickup truck in disbelief.

dialogue.text: Roper looks at the pickup truck in disbelief.

segments.content: Then he didn't say 742. He must have
said 724 or something, because this
can't be right.
Baffert unlocks the pickup and offers the keys to Roper who
is crossing to the truck.
Oh man! What am I, Red Foxx? I'm not
riding in this shit. I can't roll in
no shit like this.
He takes the keys from Baffert who moves around to the
passengers side. He opens the door.
Where's the stereo?
Fuck the stereo. What's that smell?

EXT. MARKET STREET - NIGHT The pickup in traffic. OMITTED Sequence omitted from original script. EXT. KORDA'S BUILDING - NIGHT It's a four story twenties style walk-up. It's evening now. The pickup pulls to a stop out front. INT. PICKUP - NIGHT Baffert pulls out a slip of paper.

character.name: Come on. Just get in. We gotta go.

dialogue.text: EXT. MARKET STREET - NIGHT The pickup in traffic. OMITTED Sequence omitted from original script. EXT. KORDA'S BUILDING - NIGHT It's a four story twenties style walk-up. It's evening now. The pickup pulls to a stop out front. INT. PICKUP - NIGHT Baffert pulls out a slip of paper.

segments.content: Apartment 306.
You want me to go up with you?
Nah, It probably won't turn up
anything. I'm just gonna talk to

Window open with sun streaming in, and a good view of the building across the street. We hear ROPER'S VOICE from out in the hall.

dialogue.text: At that moment, a scream echoes down from the third floor window. Roper heads for the front door of the building. INT. APT. HALLWAY/STAIRCASE - (ACROSS THE STREET) McCall bounds up the stairs of the building to the rooftop. INT. 6TH ST. APARTMENT BUILDING HALLWAY - DAY The screams are getting more panicky. Roper comes down the hall quickly. The door to the apartment is open. It's been that way since the guy in the green slacks fled. Roper hurries toward the door. INT. APARTMENT - DAY The WIFE is in bra and panties and the HUSBAND is 6'4". He's giving her a good beating. It's a studio apartment. Unmade bed. Belongings strewn all over. Window open with sun streaming in, and a good view of the building across the street. We hear ROPER'S VOICE from out in the hall.

segments.content: The husband snatches his wife by the hair and holds a knife to her throat.

character.name: I'm coming in. I'm not armed.

dialogue.text: The husband snatches his wife by the hair and holds a knife to her throat.

segments.content: (shrieking)
No, Raymond!
(to Roper)
But Roper steps into the apartment. Sees the wife. Face swollen. Knife to her neck. The enraged husband, contemplating murder. One inch from committing the act. Roper doesn't bat an eye.

character.name: Stay the fuck out of here!

dialogue.text: But Roper steps into the apartment. Sees the wife. Face swollen. Knife to her neck. The enraged husband, contemplating murder. One inch from committing the act. Roper doesn't bat an eye.

segments.content: I know how you feel, Ray.
You don't know shit, and I suggest
you leave.
He presses the knife against the wife's throat. She winces.
Her chest heaves.
I can't leave, Ray. It's part of my
negotiator's oath. Once I'm in the
room with the hostage, I have to
stay.
You don't want to see what I'm going
to do to her.
Roper reaches into his pocket and pulls out his wallet. He extracts a photo. CLOSEUP PHOTO Wife. Two kids. A little dog-eared. Nice touch. ROPER holds it up so Raymond can see it.

character.name: Let me show you something, Ray.

dialogue.text: Roper reaches into his pocket and pulls out his wallet. He extracts a photo. CLOSEUP PHOTO Wife. Two kids. A little dog-eared. Nice touch. ROPER holds it up so Raymond can see it.

segments.content: Same thing happened to me, man. She
cheated on me, but I forgave her.
You know why?
I ain't interested in your life story.
Because I was partially to blame. I
wasn't around as much as I should
have been. I forgot how to love her.

EXT. ROOF ACROSS THE STREET - ON MCCALL In prone position. Rifle in hand. Eye to scope. POV THROUGH SIGHT of Raymond's open window. INT. RAYMOND'S APARTMENT Everyone where we left them. Roper looks at Ray with utter sincerity.

character.name: She's the one to blame. Not me.

dialogue.text: EXT. ROOF ACROSS THE STREET - ON MCCALL In prone position. Rifle in hand. Eye to scope. POV THROUGH SIGHT of Raymond's open window. INT. RAYMOND'S APARTMENT Everyone where we left them. Roper looks at Ray with utter sincerity.

segments.content: Ray, think about how she looked when
you married her. Think about how
happy you were. Don't lose that,
man. Don't give up everything.
What am I giving up? I'm laid off
last year. I'm down to my last
unemployment check. I'm out on the
streets looking for work and this
bitch is banging some asshole in my
bed.
And now Ray is crying. Blubbering actually. And he's not
that coherent.
I'm down at Consolidated and I'm
begging. I'm saying I'll take half
my pay. Eight years, man. I don't
even have to work the loading docks
anymore. I'll do maintenance. "We're
cutting back. We're streamlining,
Ray. West Central's running things
now. It's out of our hands" Fuck
them! Fuck them! FUCK THEM!
(deep sigh)
I'm gonna kill her and then I'm gonna
kill myself, 'cause I don't wanna
live anymore.
Roper reaches out to him.
Ray, if you walk out of here with
me, I'll get you a job.
Doing what? Cleaning toilets?
I can't guarantee you what it will
be. But I swear on my life, I'll
find you work.
And why the fuck would you do that
for me?
Not for you, Ray. For me. A close
friend of mine was killed this week.
The way I figure it, I stop you from
doin' what you said, I'm one up on
body count.
Who the fuck are you, Mother Teresa?
Ray stares blankly at Roper's outstretched hand, the knife clutched tightly in his fist... The wife squeezes her eyes closed. Everything waits for an excruciatingly long beat... Then...

dialogue.text: Ray stares blankly at Roper's outstretched hand, the knife clutched tightly in his fist... The wife squeezes her eyes closed. Everything waits for an excruciatingly long beat... Then...

segments.content: It's on a coat rack in the corner. But to get there he has to pass by the window. Ray drops his wife on the bed, turns and goes to get his coat. He crosses in front of the window... Reaches for the coat. POP! A bullet slams into his skull. Ray falls to the floor. The wife runs out of the room, screaming!

dialogue.text: It's on a coat rack in the corner. But to get there he has to pass by the window. Ray drops his wife on the bed, turns and goes to get his coat. He crosses in front of the window... Reaches for the coat. POP! A bullet slams into his skull. Ray falls to the floor. The wife runs out of the room, screaming!

segments.content:
He rushes over to Ray. Circle of blood soaking into the 

               carpet. Ray's empty eyes. His hand still wrapped in his coat. 

               He was dead instantly. Roper slams his fist into the wall. A 

               couple of cops, guns drawn, arrive at the doorway. Roper 

               bolts out of the room... Pounds down the hallway... Pounds 

               down the stairs... down another flight...

McCall comes across the street. Roper sees McCall, cool as 

               ever. Rifle slung over his shoulder. Roper steps into his 

               path.

heading.subject: WHO THE FUCK DO YOU THINK YOU ARE?
heading.raw_text: WHO THE FUCK DO YOU THINK YOU ARE?

segments.content:
McCall gives no answer. He pushes past Roper and continues 

               into the building.
Roper follows, screaming his head off.
Do you think because the police
department issued you a sniper rifle,
it makes you God! What the fuck goes
on in your head?
McCall, still stone-faced, reaches the apartment. Yellow
"crime scene" tape is being placed across the doorway. Cops
are tiptoeing around, surveying evidence. McCall ducks under
the tape. Roper follows.

McCall goes over to Ray's body. Crouches down. Roper comes 

               up behind him. McCall picks up the coat covering Ray's arms. 

               Clutched in Ray's hand is a gun "Saturday night special" 

               variety. McCall looks up at Roper.
SWAT is a lifesaving unit, remember?
Roper doesn't miss a beat.

character.name: I just saved a life. Yours.

dialogue.text: Roper doesn't miss a beat.

segments.content: (still angry)
You think I've never had a gun pulled
on me?! You think every fucking time
someone pulls a gun they use it?!
McCall gets to his feet.
Eighty-five percent of domestic
disturbances of this nature end in
murder/suicide.
(fiercely)
McCall and Roper glare at each other. Toe to toe. A beat. McCall's face softens just perceptibly.

dialogue.text: McCall and Roper glare at each other. Toe to toe. A beat. McCall's face softens just perceptibly.

segments.content: He walks out of the room. Roper whips the sheet off the bed, contemplates the gun gripped in Ray's hand... Then tosses the sheet over Ray's dead body. INT. METRO DIVISION - NIGHT Roper seated in the hallway, waiting outside a door marked "Internal Affairs". Things are quiet. Roper stares at the floor. Waiting. The door opens. McCall comes out, escorted by two internal affairs INVESTIGATORS. One of the investigators pats him on the back.

dialogue.text: He walks out of the room. Roper whips the sheet off the bed, contemplates the gun gripped in Ray's hand... Then tosses the sheet over Ray's dead body. INT. METRO DIVISION - NIGHT Roper seated in the hallway, waiting outside a door marked "Internal Affairs". Things are quiet. Roper stares at the floor. Waiting. The door opens. McCall comes out, escorted by two internal affairs INVESTIGATORS. One of the investigators pats him on the back.

segments.content: Looks like a clean shoot. Go home
and get some rest.
McCall shakes hands with the investigators and they disappear
back into the office. Roper approaches McCall. He's cooled
off considerably. Even a tad friendly.
Come on. Let's go for a drink.
I don't really like to drink.
You have to. It's a tradition.

INT. BILLY GOAT TAVERN - NIGHT A neighborhood bar. Roper and McCall are playing pool. Half- finished beers are on a nearby table. McCall is bent over the table trying to make a particularly tricky shot. Roper studies him.

character.name: Well, if I have to, I have to.

dialogue.text: INT. BILLY GOAT TAVERN - NIGHT A neighborhood bar. Roper and McCall are playing pool. Half- finished beers are on a nearby table. McCall is bent over the table trying to make a particularly tricky shot. Roper studies him.

segments.content: You got a girlfriend?
McCall misses the shot.

dialogue.text: McCall misses the shot.

segments.content: Roper lines up his shot.

dialogue.text: Roper lines up his shot.

segments.content: You wouldn't want to put a small
wager on this, would you?
Roper smiles. Sinks his shot. Moves around the table.

dialogue.text: Roper smiles. Sinks his shot. Moves around the table.

segments.content: Yeah, I've got a girlfriend.
You living together?
She's back in Jersey... going to
graduate school.
Explain how that works.
She's going to come here when she
graduates and then we're gonna get
married.
She grow up in Livingtston, too?
(as if that were
unthinkable)
No, no, no...
(a beat)
She's from Hoboken.
Oh, "city girl". Don't you ever long
for companionship with her such a
long way away in New Jersey?
We see each other every couple of
months.
A couple of months sounds like an awful long time to Roper.

dialogue.text: A couple of months sounds like an awful long time to Roper.

segments.content: That's a lot of commitment. I admire
that.
Do you really?
No. Actually I think it's fucking
crazy, I don't know if I could do
it.
Thanks for clearing that up.
(a beat)
I hear your former girlfriend is
going out with Greg Barnett.
Where did you hear that?
Around. Barnett's tough competition.
Yeah, well that's a sore subject,
and therefore out of bounds to a
young sprout of a hostage negotiator
under my tutelage.
A beat and then McCall realizes that this comment is a major
acknowledgement of acceptance from Roper. Roper misses his

heading.subject: shot. Picks up his beer glass.
heading.raw_text: shot. Picks up his beer glass.

segments.content: Lesson two, "Dead Eye"... should
have been lesson one. Never exchange
yourself for a hostage.
I think I can handle that one.
Roper takes a drink of beer. Nears the bottom of his glass. Calls to the BARTENDER.

character.name: Yeah, you think so, but it comes up.

dialogue.text: Roper takes a drink of beer. Nears the bottom of his glass. Calls to the BARTENDER.

segments.content: Roper turns back to McCall.

dialogue.text: Roper turns back to McCall.

segments.content: My partner gave himself in exchange
for a ten year old girl. He got caught
in the crossfire. Two dead. My partner
and the bad guy...
(takes the last sip)
Weird thing is, if he was alive,
he'd probably do it again.
(a beat)
Roper puts down his glass.

dialogue.text: Roper puts down his glass.

segments.content: You think you can learn, McCall?
Roper nods. Maybe he can. INT. ROOM - DAY We're looking at a door. It's not clear where we are. McCall enters. We only see his face. Determined.

dialogue.text: Roper nods. Maybe he can. INT. ROOM - DAY We're looking at a door. It's not clear where we are. McCall enters. We only see his face. Determined.

segments.content: REVERSE ANGLE It's a training room. It's built to approximate a convenience store. Several mannequins are placed around the room to represent a hostage situation. The "BAD GUY" has a walkie- talkie strapped around his neck. Roper's voice CRACKLES out of it.

character.name: I'm Officer McCall, what's going on?

dialogue.text: REVERSE ANGLE It's a training room. It's built to approximate a convenience store. Several mannequins are placed around the room to represent a hostage situation. The "BAD GUY" has a walkie- talkie strapped around his neck. Roper's voice CRACKLES out of it.

segments.content: What the fuck do you think is going
on, turdhead? I'm about to waste
everyone in this place.
McCall hesitates, trying to figure out a response. He seems
stiff and awkward.
H... how can I help you? Tell me
what...
(looks off to his
right)
Roper enters the training room from a side door. He's holding the other walkie-talkie.

character.name: I feel stupid talking to a dummy.

dialogue.text: Roper enters the training room from a side door. He's holding the other walkie-talkie.

segments.content: What did you think? I'm going to let
you practice on real people?
Roper comes up beside him.
First things is, don't say, "What's
going on?" Everybody knows what's
going on. I come into this situation,
I say,
(addressing the
mannequin)
"I'm glad to see nobody's hurt. That's
good. I'm here to help you."
(turns back to McCall)
Second: You hesitated. Don't hesitate.
If you're thinking, talk while you're
thinking, or else he's going to think
you're plotting. Which you are. If
he thinks you're plotting, you're
going to make him nervous. You don't
want him nervous. Got that?
No.
INT. TRAINING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER ANGLE ON THE DOOR. McCall comes in. The room has the same set-up. McCall takes a look around. Launches immediately into...

dialogue.text: INT. TRAINING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER ANGLE ON THE DOOR. McCall comes in. The room has the same set-up. McCall takes a look around. Launches immediately into...

segments.content: My name's McCall. I'm a hostage
negotiator. I'm here to help you.
Roper's voice crackles back at him hostilely.
McCall's confidence is growing.

character.name: How are you going to help me?

dialogue.text: McCall's confidence is growing.

segments.content: Tell me what you need.
I need you to bring me the scumbag
who ran off with my wife so I can
cut off his nuts.
Now he's stumped.
(hesitantly)
I can't do that.
Then get out of my face you worthless
piece of frogshit.
McCall looks up to his right.
Roper re-enters the training area.

character.name: Is all the name calling necessary.

dialogue.text: Roper re-enters the training area.

segments.content: Nah, I just throw that in because I
enjoy it.
(exasperated)
So what do I say to this guy?
You could say something like,
(addressing the dummy)
"Tell me what the scumbag's name is.
Maybe we can work something out."
What? Bring somebody in so he can
cut his nuts off?
Roper turns to McCall.
If you want to be a successful
negotiator, you've got to learn to
lie.
I'm not good at lying.
Get good at it.
Roper gives him an amused smile.

dialogue.text: Roper gives him an amused smile.

segments.content: You know the ten commandments?
Yes.
What's the first commandment?
Thou shall have no other God before
me.
That's not the answer Roper wanted.
Okay, forget that. What's the main
one.
McCall is tired of guessing.
You tell me.
Thou shall not kill... You've killed,
right?
Yes.
Why?
To save lives.
So why would you hesitate to lie to
save lives?
McCall can't argue with that one. Roper turns and heads back
to the side door.

INT. TRAINING ROOM - LATER McCall comes through the door. Hands in the air. The setup in the room has been changed a bit. The bad guy is behind the counter. Several hostages in various positions on the floor.

dialogue.text: INT. TRAINING ROOM - LATER McCall comes through the door. Hands in the air. The setup in the room has been changed a bit. The bad guy is behind the counter. Several hostages in various positions on the floor.

segments.content: My name's McCall. I'm unarmed.
Roper comes through the side door.

dialogue.text: Roper comes through the side door.

segments.content: McCall is surprised by the command but closes them. Roper turns him away from the hostage scene.

dialogue.text: McCall is surprised by the command but closes them. Roper turns him away from the hostage scene.

segments.content: What did you see?
(rapid-fire)
A dirtbag behind the counter holding
a sawed-off. A Berretta nine
millimeter in his belt. A female
hostage, red dress, on the floor in
front of the cereal display. Male
hostage, jeans and blue checked shirt,
three feet to her right. Another
male hostage, white pants, green
shirt, Nikes, laying in front of the
magazine rack. A female dirtbag with
a gun under her shirt, sitting against
the beer cooler, trying to pass
herself off as a hostage, and there's
a special on toilet-paper, four for
a buck twenty-nine.
McCall opens his eyes. Roper's impressed.
Very good. You've got good eyes.

INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY Roper and McCall are sitting in the dark watching a video tape. It's grainy footage of a hostage situation in a sporting goods store. A negotiator confronted with a gunman holding a ten year old girl hostage. The negotiator holds his hands out imploringly... Carefully moves toward the gunman. The negotiator exchanges himself for the little girl. The gunman grabs the negotiator around the neck, holds the gun to his head. The little girl runs out of the picture to safety. Roper remains dead silent during all this. McCall looks over at him. The blue light flickers over Roper's motionless face.

dialogue.text: INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - DAY Roper and McCall are sitting in the dark watching a video tape. It's grainy footage of a hostage situation in a sporting goods store. A negotiator confronted with a gunman holding a ten year old girl hostage. The negotiator holds his hands out imploringly... Carefully moves toward the gunman. The negotiator exchanges himself for the little girl. The gunman grabs the negotiator around the neck, holds the gun to his head. The little girl runs out of the picture to safety. Roper remains dead silent during all this. McCall looks over at him. The blue light flickers over Roper's motionless face.

segments.content: Roper nods.

dialogue.text: Roper nods.

segments.content: Why did he do it?
(quietly)
Because he knew the little girl had
zero chance of survival and his
chances would be a little better...
We had a plan, but SWAT opened up
too early. He got caught in the
crossfire.
(a sad beat)
Let's move on... Notice this. Always
use the eyes to keep the connection.
It almost like hypnosis. That's the
most important thing. Create a
connection. You're always on their
side...
McCall watches him for a beat, then turns his attention back
on the screen.

Beautiful day. Roper and McCall leaning against the rail at 

               the walking ring. The horses are being paraded and saddled. 

               Roper scrutinizes them with an expert eye. McCall seems 

               totally disinterested.
You know why I like the track?
Roper ignores that.

dialogue.text: Roper ignores that.

segments.content: Because there are a multitude of
possibility's. Everything is there
to see if you know what to look for.
You have to read the conditions,
just like in a hostage situation.
Roper points across the ring to a particular horse.
See the four horse. Dropping in class.
No works. Front wraps. Looks like
he's broken down. But notice the
woman in the sun hat. She's the owner.
She wouldn't have come if her horse
was broken down. He's live. We use
him.
McCall listens indifferently.
See the favorite? Tail up. Washy. He
doesn't want to run today. Cross him
off... Now the Six looks good. On
his toes. Coat shiny. This
trainer/jockey combo does well. We
can't leave him out.
(turns to McCall)
What do you think?
I have two words for you... Seek
help.
I have three words for you... Ex-ac-
ta.

Roper is buying tickets. McCall is with him, watching the 

               other bettors, the odds board, all the monitors... Strange 

               place. Roper finishes and turns away from the window. Hands 

               McCall a ticket.
I bought you a four-six exacta box.
You owe me twenty bucks.
(puzzled)
EXT. SEATING AREA - DAY Roper and McCall pass by a gambler.

dialogue.text: EXT. SEATING AREA - DAY Roper and McCall pass by a gambler.

segments.content: Hey, Roper.
They sit down in a box right up front.

dialogue.text: They sit down in a box right up front.

segments.content: We need the 4 and 6 to finish to
first and second.
(no enthusiasm)
Roper uses his binoculars to watch the horses warm up on the backstretch.

dialogue.text: Roper uses his binoculars to watch the horses warm up on the backstretch.

segments.content: I'm told that newspaper photographer
is your former girlfriend.
Roper looks over at him. What's this about?
Ronnie... Yeah, so.
Now she's going out with Greg Barnett?
So what do you want?... An autograph.
I don't know why she'd pick him over
you.
Roper throws McCall a skeptical look.
(straight-faced)
I'm just practicing my lying.
Still needs work.
(downcast)
You're right. I'll never be as good
a liar as you.
ON THE TRACK The horses spring from the gate. (The track announcer's call plays through race) IN THE STANDS Roper watches intently through the binoculars. McCall sits impassively.

dialogue.text: ON THE TRACK The horses spring from the gate. (The track announcer's call plays through race) IN THE STANDS Roper watches intently through the binoculars. McCall sits impassively.

segments.content: Okay, we're in good shape. We're in
good shape.
McCall looks across the track.
The 6 horse is last.
That's okay. That's his style.
To run last?
Roper follows the horses into the turn.

dialogue.text: Roper follows the horses into the turn.

segments.content: The favorite's fading. I told you he
wasn't going to run today... The
four horse has got the lead!
McCall sits like a wax figure.
(cynically)
The 6 horse is still last.
ON THE TRACK The horses head into the stretch. The FOUR is on the lead and the SIX is starting to unleash a big run. Passing horses with every stride.

character.name: He'll be running at the quarter pole.

dialogue.text: ON THE TRACK The horses head into the stretch. The FOUR is on the lead and the SIX is starting to unleash a big run. Passing horses with every stride.

segments.content: IN THE STANDS McCall sits forward slightly.

dialogue.text: IN THE STANDS McCall sits forward slightly.

segments.content: They need to run first and second?
Roper gets to his feet. ON THE TRACK The horses thunder down the stretch. The FOUR horse is in front and the SIX is coming on from behind. IN THE STANDS Roper is on his feet screaming.

dialogue.text: Roper gets to his feet. ON THE TRACK The horses thunder down the stretch. The FOUR horse is in front and the SIX is coming on from behind. IN THE STANDS Roper is on his feet screaming.

segments.content: McCall jumps to this feet and joins him.

character.name: Come on, Russell! Come on, Russell.

dialogue.text: McCall jumps to this feet and joins him.

segments.content: (to Roper)
Who the fuck's Russell?!
The jockey!
Roper and McCall cheer together.

The FOUR horse crosses the finish line in front. The SIX 

               horse is flying... Needs to beat one horse to be second... 

               He's running out of room... With one last surge he hits the 

               wire and... It's too close to call.
McCall, really excited, turns to Roper.
We won!
(disheartened)
We lost.
(confidently)
We won.
How much you wanna bet?
You want to bet on whether you won
your bet? This is getting sick.

As the photo finish light goes out and the numbers come on... 

               4-6-8. They won.
High fives.

dialogue.text: High fives.

segments.content: INT. BET/CASH WINDOW - DAY Roper and McCall collect their money. Four hundred a piece, not bad. McCall pockets his money.

dialogue.text: INT. BET/CASH WINDOW - DAY Roper and McCall collect their money. Four hundred a piece, not bad. McCall pockets his money.

segments.content: How long you been coming here?
About six years. My partner took me.
Is it always like this?
Suddenly Roper's BEEPER goes off. He checks it, takes out a cellular phone and dials.

dialogue.text: Suddenly Roper's BEEPER goes off. He checks it, takes out a cellular phone and dials.

segments.content: (into the phone)
Roper here.
(he listens)
He hangs up and turns to McCall.

dialogue.text: He hangs up and turns to McCall.

segments.content: EXT. JEWELRY STORE - UNION SQUARE - DAY Marble facade. Tastefully reinforced windows and door. Choppers circle overhead. Both ends of the street are sealed off. Barricades are up. Spectators and news crews crowd behind those. Numerous police circulate. This is a major operation in full swing. INT. TRAVEL AGENCY - COMMAND CENTER - DAY It's across the street from the jewelry store. Second story. The walls are plastered with travel posters. A poster of Tahiti is the most prominent. Members of police and SWAT are standing over a blueprint of the jewelry store spread out on a table. Right behind them is a TV monitoring the front of the store. Solis is at another desk, on the phone. He's talking to the suspect.

dialogue.text: EXT. JEWELRY STORE - UNION SQUARE - DAY Marble facade. Tastefully reinforced windows and door. Choppers circle overhead. Both ends of the street are sealed off. Barricades are up. Spectators and news crews crowd behind those. Numerous police circulate. This is a major operation in full swing. INT. TRAVEL AGENCY - COMMAND CENTER - DAY It's across the street from the jewelry store. Second story. The walls are plastered with travel posters. A poster of Tahiti is the most prominent. Members of police and SWAT are standing over a blueprint of the jewelry store spread out on a table. Right behind them is a TV monitoring the front of the store. Solis is at another desk, on the phone. He's talking to the suspect.

segments.content: We're working on that, Joe. These
things aren't quite that simple.

Roper and McCall push through the barricades and come walking 

               down the cordoned-off street. McCall takes a look at the 

               jewelry store. Well fortified, foreboding.
Roper looks over there, gives no reaction. They reach Solis' convertible Cadillac. It's parked out front of the travel agency building.

dialogue.text: Roper looks over there, gives no reaction. They reach Solis' convertible Cadillac. It's parked out front of the travel agency building.

segments.content: See this. Solis has me driving the
shit-mobile, and he picked this up
straight out of impound for fourteen
grand. Probably worth thirty.
INT. COMMAND POST - DAY Roper and McCall enter. McCall joins the men who are studying the blueprint. Roper stands by Solis and listens, takes note of the poster of Tahiti. Looks inviting.

dialogue.text: INT. COMMAND POST - DAY Roper and McCall enter. McCall joins the men who are studying the blueprint. Roper stands by Solis and listens, takes note of the poster of Tahiti. Looks inviting.

segments.content: This will take time to setup. I'll
have to get authorizations.
(he listens)
Solis pulls the phone away from his ear. Joe has obviously hung up.

dialogue.text: Solis pulls the phone away from his ear. Joe has obviously hung up.

segments.content: What do we got?
32 minutes ago the silent alarm went
off, then the fire alarm. A unit was
a block away, and the suspect got
trapped inside.
Any verification on numbers.
We've only seen and talked to one
suspect. He calls himself "Joe".
There's two jewelers, two salespeople,
the manager, a security guard, and
an elderly woman. This particular
store is where they do a lot of
jewelry making and repair. They have
anywhere from 8 to 10 million in raw
stones on any given day, so they
sure as shit didn't just wander in.
They knew what they were coming for.
What have you promised them?
McCall returns from checking out the blueprints.

character.name: Just that I'd talk to my superiors.

dialogue.text: McCall returns from checking out the blueprints.

segments.content: McCall shakes his head.

dialogue.text: McCall shakes his head.

segments.content: Roper picks up the cellular phone. It dials automatically.

character.name: The place is designed to be a vault.

dialogue.text: Roper picks up the cellular phone. It dials automatically.

segments.content: (into the phone)
My name's Roper. How are you people
doing in there?
(he listens)
Solis is off the job now, Joe. I'm
the guy authorized to give you
whatever you want.
(listens)
That's right, but first I need to
come down there to talk to you.

We don't see anything but the suspect on the other end of 

               the phone. He's wearing a ski mask and gloves. Totally 

               unrecognizable to the audience. We will find out soon that 

               he is, in fact, Korda. He appears very cool and collected.
INT. COMMAND CENTER - DAY

character.name: You don't have to come here.

dialogue.text: INT. COMMAND CENTER - DAY

segments.content: Yes, I do. That way there's no
misunderstandings. I need to make
sure no one's hurt, then we can take
care of business.
A long pause... Then a bit sinister.
Alright, Roper. You want to come...
come.
Good. I won't be armed. We gotta
operate on trust here. We're going
to wrap this up and have you guys
out of here as soon as possible.
Roper clicks off the phone. He already doesn't like the sound
of this guy.

heading.raw_text: EXT. STREET OUTSIDE JEWELRY STORE - DAY

segments.content:
Roper, bulletproof vest, hands in the air, walks across the 

               eerily deserted street straight toward the jewelry store. 

               It's quiet now. The choppers have been pulled back.

               Roper reaches the sidewalk right in front of the store. Korda 

               cracks the door open.
(warningly)
Roper stops in his tracks.

dialogue.text: Roper stops in his tracks.

segments.content: Roper slowly lowers his hands. INT. COMMAND CENTER Everybody watching through the window. EXT. JEWELRY STORE - DAY Korda takes a half step out the doorway. The gloved hand that is visible is not holding a weapon. The other half of his body is hidden inside the doorway. He wears jeans, a black shirt, and black Nike tennis shoes. He stares fiercely from behind the ski mask. There's no sign of fear in him.

character.name: I'm going to put my hands down, okay.

dialogue.text: Roper slowly lowers his hands. INT. COMMAND CENTER Everybody watching through the window. EXT. JEWELRY STORE - DAY Korda takes a half step out the doorway. The gloved hand that is visible is not holding a weapon. The other half of his body is hidden inside the doorway. He wears jeans, a black shirt, and black Nike tennis shoes. He stares fiercely from behind the ski mask. There's no sign of fear in him.

segments.content: Are you in charge, Roper?
Yep.
I want a car. Like a four wheel drive.
I want it in perfect condition. I
want a uniformed cop to drive it up
right here. I want him to leave the
engine running and walk to the end
of the street. Then we'll come out.
I don't want any remote control
devices in it. I know all the tricks.
If it's not in perfect condition,
and I mean if its even low on wiper
fluid, I'm going to kill somebody
and we're gonna start again.
Korda lets that sink in.
I want a plane waiting at the airport.
I'll tell them where I want to go
when I get there.
Is that all?
For now that's all.
You'll get it. But, Joe, I want you
to do something for me. Let me take
a look around inside. Make sure
everybody's okay.
No. You just do shit for me right
now.
Korda's eyes glare from behind the ski mask. He's an ominous
figure.
Joe, I'm doing a lot for you. I think
you could give me something to cement
the deal... One hostage.
Korda pulls a wadded-up handkerchief out of his pocket and tosses it to Roper. Roper unwraps the handkerchief. DETAIL SHOT It's a human ear.

dialogue.text: Korda pulls a wadded-up handkerchief out of his pocket and tosses it to Roper. Roper unwraps the handkerchief. DETAIL SHOT It's a human ear.

segments.content: In fifteen minutes it'll be a bigger
piece. I assume there are no
"misunderstanding".
Roper is as serious as we've ever seen him.

Korda disappears back behind the door. EXT. COMMAND CENTER - DAY Roper trudges back in. Things are more active now. Logistical officers are making flow charts. Photos of the hostages are being posted on a bulletin board. Roper approaches Solis, McCall and the SWAT CAPTAIN who are anxiously waiting for his report.

dialogue.text: Korda disappears back behind the door. EXT. COMMAND CENTER - DAY Roper trudges back in. Things are more active now. Logistical officers are making flow charts. Photos of the hostages are being posted on a bulletin board. Roper approaches Solis, McCall and the SWAT CAPTAIN who are anxiously waiting for his report.

segments.content: (flatly)
We're going to have to take this guy
out.
That draws a long silence. That's something Roper rarely
says.
Roper hands Solis the handkerchief with the ear in it. Solis eyes it with dismay.

dialogue.text: Roper hands Solis the handkerchief with the ear in it. Solis eyes it with dismay.

segments.content: I believe there's at least one
fatality in there already. The fire
alarm was probably set off by gunfire.
I believe he's working alone, both
from his conversation and the fact
that he wouldn't come out beyond the
doorway. He was holding a gun on the
hostages while he was talking to me.
His demeanor is calm and controlled,
that's what really scares me. The
other bad news is that he also
indicated a familiarity with our
techniques.
(a beat)
So, do you want to go in or wait for
him to come out?
McCall calmly offers his opinion.
Let him come out. Too many unknowns
in there.
Solis nods. That'll be the plan.
When we drive up the car, make sure

heading.subject: about three feet
heading.raw_text: it's at an angle about three feet

segments.content: from the curb.
(to SWAT Captain)
Put our best man "highground", Twenty
The SWAT Captain motions and turns to one of his UNDERLINGS.
Have Anderson prep it and notify us
when he's on line.
The underling hurries off to take care of it. Solis looks at
Roper dejectedly.
I feel this thing going sideways on
us.
Roper tries to buck him up.
There is some good news. He's wearing
a ski mask, so he's protecting his
identity and hasn't determined to
kill all the hostages...
(big pause)

INT. JEWELRY STORE - DAY The jewel thief pulls off his ski mask to reveal he is Korda. His face is sweaty. Hair matted. ANGLE WIDENS to show five very scared hostages: A JEWELER, middle-aged, balding. The male MANAGER, good-looking, thirties, three piece suit. TWO SALESGIRLS, nicely dressed, late twenties. A FEMALE CUSTOMER, gray-haired Hillsborough matron. They are all seated against the wall. There are two fatalities lying on the floor. The guard and one of the jewelers. Korda points his gun at the manager and the other jeweler and motions to the dead bodies.

dialogue.text: INT. JEWELRY STORE - DAY The jewel thief pulls off his ski mask to reveal he is Korda. His face is sweaty. Hair matted. ANGLE WIDENS to show five very scared hostages: A JEWELER, middle-aged, balding. The male MANAGER, good-looking, thirties, three piece suit. TWO SALESGIRLS, nicely dressed, late twenties. A FEMALE CUSTOMER, gray-haired Hillsborough matron. They are all seated against the wall. There are two fatalities lying on the floor. The guard and one of the jewelers. Korda points his gun at the manager and the other jeweler and motions to the dead bodies.

segments.content: The two men reluctantly get to their feet and commence the grim task. The two salesgirls watch Korda fearfully. The older female customer seems to be in a lesser state of reality. Her eyes are a bit far away. Korda moves over to the remaining display cases that haven't been looted. With the barrel of his gun, He SMASHES the glass, reaches in and picks out the jewelry. He dumps it in an open satchel already half-filled with packets of raw gemstones and gold chains. Suddenly, the older woman customer gets to her feet. She seems fairly out-of-it. Maybe in shock. She starts walking toward the front door frowning with dissatisfaction.

dialogue.text: The two men reluctantly get to their feet and commence the grim task. The two salesgirls watch Korda fearfully. The older female customer seems to be in a lesser state of reality. Her eyes are a bit far away. Korda moves over to the remaining display cases that haven't been looted. With the barrel of his gun, He SMASHES the glass, reaches in and picks out the jewelry. He dumps it in an open satchel already half-filled with packets of raw gemstones and gold chains. Suddenly, the older woman customer gets to her feet. She seems fairly out-of-it. Maybe in shock. She starts walking toward the front door frowning with dissatisfaction.

segments.content: I'm not staying here another minute.
(panicky)
Korda rushes around the display case.

dialogue.text: Korda rushes around the display case.

segments.content: He grabs a handful of the woman's coiffed gray hair and drags her away from the door. She shrieks. The manager takes a step toward Korda.

dialogue.text: He grabs a handful of the woman's coiffed gray hair and drags her away from the door. She shrieks. The manager takes a step toward Korda.

segments.content: Korda pistol whips her across the forehead and drops her unconscious to the floor then turns the gun on the manager.

dialogue.text: Korda pistol whips her across the forehead and drops her unconscious to the floor then turns the gun on the manager.

segments.content: The manager glares at him. He's about Korda's size. He thinks about making a run at him.

character.name: You're a brave one, aren't you?

dialogue.text: The manager glares at him. He's about Korda's size. He thinks about making a run at him.

segments.content: (pleading)
A long beat... The manager sits back down on the floor with the other hostages. Salesgirl 1 is giving aid to the old woman. Korda looks down at her.

dialogue.text: A long beat... The manager sits back down on the floor with the other hostages. Salesgirl 1 is giving aid to the old woman. Korda looks down at her.

segments.content: If she's not conscious when it's
time to leave, I'll have to kill
her.
Korda goes back to the display cases to collect the rest of
the gems.

Cops clear spectators out of the way as a green FORD EXPLORER 

               RUMBLES through the barricade and heads down the deserted 

               street.

Roper and McCall at the window, attention fixed on the store. 

               The Explorer crawls to a stop in front of the jewelry store.

heading.subject: police officer gets
heading.raw_text: Parks at a slight angle. The uniformed police officer gets

segments.content:
out, leaving the engine running, and walks off back to the 

               barricade.
Okay. Time to give this fucker a
call.
Roper picks up the phone, waits. Everybody tensely watching
the store.
Sequence omitted from original script.
A sniper team watching the store from a third floor window.
Roper holding the phone. It's still ringing.
Another sharpshooting team. Poised. Waiting.
And still another sharpshooter team.
The phone is still ringing.
Just then, the front door of the jewelry store swings open. A spray of white vapor shoots out the doorway. Korda is discharging a fire extinguisher.

dialogue.text: Just then, the front door of the jewelry store swings open. A spray of white vapor shoots out the doorway. Korda is discharging a fire extinguisher.

segments.content: There's your answer. He's smart.
He's cutting down the visibility.
A thick cloud of white hangs over the sidewalk obscuring the front of the jewelry store. Roper puts down the phone.

character.name: And doing a very good job of it.

dialogue.text: A thick cloud of white hangs over the sidewalk obscuring the front of the jewelry store. Roper puts down the phone.

heading.subject: Come on. Give us one clean shot.
heading.raw_text: Come on. Give us one clean shot.

segments.content: (into his radio)
All positions, you have the green
light.

Roper grabs a pair of binoculars. HIS POV Through the haze, we catch glimpses of the hostages circled around the figure in the ski mask. They slowly shuffle toward the Explorer. McCall watches intently. EXT. ROOFTOP - SAME A sniper watches through his scope. Finger poised on the trigger. ANGLE THROUGH THE SCOPE Low visibility through the haze. The figure in the ski mask wavers in and out of the crosshairs, shielded momentarily by the jeweler, then he flashes back into the crosshairs. The sniper tries to lock him in. INT. COMMAND CENTER - ROPER'S POV - BINOCULARS - SAME The figure in the ski mask leans slightly and Roper catches a glimpse of the hostage right behind him. Roper recognizes him instantly.

dialogue.text: Roper grabs a pair of binoculars. HIS POV Through the haze, we catch glimpses of the hostages circled around the figure in the ski mask. They slowly shuffle toward the Explorer.
